communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

PALESTINE-SYRIA MAIL SERVICE—The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh, and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larcena (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrha, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople..

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.—The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suex alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE—Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

div.head: YELLOW PERIL ON THE PACIFIC.
div.p: "As one war cloud vanishes another looms visible in the distant horizon, now of the political, now of the economical variety. But of all the dangers to peace which have disquieted statesmen and nations in modern times the 'Yellow Peril' is perhaps the most serious," writes Dr. E. J. Dillon in the September "Contemporary Review."

"The Pacific question is the rock against which the pacific endeavours of The Hagne Conference may be unable to prevail. Americansare resolved, consciously or unconsciously, to effect the commercial conquest of the Far East. And if they lacked the deliberate intention they would none the less aspire instinctively, perseveringly to the acquisition of commercial supremacy there. For it is an economic necessity. Whether, as some fancy, & tonnel will ultimately join the United States in the North with Asia, and Manila become a vast emporium for American manufactures to be exported to South China is a detail of no great importance. The cardinal fact is the tendency of the people of the United States to look upon the Far East as the special market for their industrial output and to become more and more dependent upon it. Industrial and commercial supremacy there will become in consequence & necessity, a matter of vital importance, and the struggle for it a struggle for life and death. And Japan is and will remain the most serious competitor of the United States. Probably in this rivalry rather than in any racial incompatibility lies the source of the dispute between the representatives of the white and yellow peoples, the earliest phase of which is visible in California.

"The Japanese are not only the most formidable competitors of the people America for the markets of the Far East, they are also the most serious rivals of every other people for any and every prize worth striving for. And they are this, not because they are a whit worse than their neighbours, morally, intelletually, or physically, but in virtue of qualities which we have hitherto professed to esteem and coltative, but which we now have reason to apprehend. In other words, the root of the matter seems too deep for any of the surgical instruments known to diplomacy. Already the struggle has begun. For the Japanese, whose efforts are methodical, do not allow the grass to grow under their feet. The strides they make are gigantic. The rapidity, for instance, with which industry was introduced into Nippon and coltivated and developed there is suggestive of the quasi-miraculous growth of the mango plant under the mysterious manipulations of the Oriental juggler.

"They work under conditions not dreamed of by the European. There is no really vexations workman's legislation, there are no costly responsibilities to bear, and low wages are paid which even African natives would sneer at. What they lacked in their island home the Japs have acquired in Korea, and within a few years the land of the Morning Calm, dotted over with factories, covered with a network of railways and governed by laws drafted or suggested by the wisest of living statesmen, Hirobumi Ito, may become the Lancashire of the Extreme Orient And then ? Will & Conference sitting in the Huis ten Bosch, between The Hague and the ocean, cry Thus far and no farther,' with reasonable hope of being heard and hearkened to ?

"It should not be forgotten that this planet of ours contains in round numbers some 1520 millions of human beings struggling to keep body and soul together. Approximately 830 millions of these are in Asia, and only 690 millions scattered over the remainder of the globe. Consequently more than half the human race inhabits the old Continent whence our civilisation took its origin. What will happen when those masses awaken from the lethargy of centuries and grow conscious at once of their needs and their strength ? Already China is rising slowly from the coma in which it was plunged. Having accepted Europe's advice and exhortations it is returning slowly to militarism and there are children now living among us who may not die before China has an army of two millions to defend its vital interests, which assuredly will not be identical with those of the white men of Europe or the United States. And the more intelligent of these children will known that China's transformation was the work of their own fathers."

div.head: Cotton Worm
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has discharged 15 more employés who were engaged upon Cotton Worm work.

div.head: Coptic New Year.
div.p: The new Coptic year 1624, commenced yesterday. The Te Deum was sung in the Coptic Church in honour of the occasion.

div.head: Book Club.
div.p: The Alexandria Book Club will open from 3.45 p.m., to 5 p.m. on Tuesdays and Fridays from the 17th inst, inclusive.

div.head: Police Budget.
div.p: 6 thefts, 17 misdemeanours and 59 minor offences came under the notice of the police in Cairo and its suburbs during the course of Wednesday.

div.head: Repression of Slave Trade.
div.p: Three Sudanese women in Cairo, 4 in Alex andria and 2 at Suez were liberated by the Repression of Slave Trade Department during the past month.

div.head: Drowning Fatality.
div.p: While bathing in El Gabal canal on Wednesday evening, Hussein El Samkain, got out of his depth and sank before help could be given. When the body was eventually recovered life was extinct and the body was duly buried.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: Two admissions to, and one recovery in, hospital at Alexandria and one admission and one death at Sembelladine were the only details of bubonic plague reported throughout Egypt during the past 24 hours. Six patients are still under treatment.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: 131 fatal cases of bovine plague were registered throughout Egypt during the week ending the 9th instant, of which 6 occurred in the province of Kalioubia, 1 in that of Sharkia, 107 in the district of Assiout and 17 at Guirga.

div.head: Canal Company.
div.p: We understand that the Suez Canal Company proposes to augment the salaries of their employés, receiving less than 6,000 francs per annum. Those who are married will shortly receive an increase of 10% and those unmarried of 5%.

div.head: A Fatal Accident.
div.p: A serious accident occurred yesterday morning at Ghezireh Palace at about eleven o'clock when the floor of one of the rooms of the Hotel collapsed killing a native care taker, named Ibrahim Ismail. After the usual police enquiry had been made, an order was granted for the burial of the victim.

div.head: The "Olivemoor".
div.p: The reports concerning the situation of the " Olivemoor” are more favourable. The "Bergher Wilhelm” has continued pumping incessantly and it is hoped that the vessel will be got off the rocks late this afternoon. At the time of writing the forward part of the vessel is reported to have been raised.

div.head: A Wrestler's Death.
div.p: The death of one of the wrestler's engaged in the present struggle for the world's championship at Cairo, has created great regret among the competitors and those who have gathered at the meetings. The deceased was a Dutchman named Hans Hansen, aged 18 years, whose father is a noted athlete. His death was due to ptomaine poisoning.

div.head: Fires in Cairo.
div.p: The Cairo Fire Brigade was twice called out in the course of Wednesday to extinguish fires which occurred in Haret el Zaafar and Sharia Abbassi. In both cases the alarm was promptly given and the brigade was thus enabled to check the conflagrations before any really serious damage was done. In the former case the fire is attributed to the careless throwing away of a cigarette end and in the latter to the fusing of an electric wire which set fire to a silk curtain.

div.head: Carriage Accident.
div.p: A serious accident which occurred at Cairo yesterday. shows the necessity of placing lights where the roads are being mended, or are encumbered with building material, in order to give due warning at night. About 9 p.m. Dr. Dorra was returning home in has carriage through the rue El Nozha, when the carriage collided with a heap of building - material which the coachman had not noticed, owing to there being no lantern to mark the place. The carriage overturned and both the doctor and his coachman were thrown out, the former receiving injuries which rendered him unconscious while the latter was able to secure aid, and procure means to transport the doctor to his home.

div.head: INSPECTION COMMITTEE APPOINTED.
div.p: The second adjourned meeting of the Bourse and Banking Co. of Egypt, Ltd. was held at the offices of the Company, Rue Cherif Pasha, yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock, and although protracted until nearly 8 o'clock, the proceedings under the presidency of the imperturbable M. Maroni were conducted without any excessive display of warmth or loss of temper.

As at the previous meeting Maitre Mercinier represented Messrs Arditi who were again absent, thus ignoring the resolution of the shareholders of which they had received notice inviting their attendance for the purpose of explaining the manner in which the affairs of the company have been conducted. Maitre Mercinier defended their absence on the ground that Mr. J. Arditi was entitled to preside at the meeting and was justified in refusing to attend in the apologetic position to which his colleagues appeared to wish to relegate him. This contention did not commend itself to the meeting : and the absence of Messrs. Arditi and Mr. Gré was censured. The chairman endeavoured to limit the discussion to the motion of the directors for voluntary liquidation ; but Messrs. Mercinier, J. Aghion, Lapommeraye and others insisted on examining the accounts submitted by the auditors, which will be published on page 4 in tomorrow's issue, and questioning the transactions of the Arditis and Mr. R. Ghilio. Several shareholders addressed the meeting : and at times the discussion was carried on simultaneously by so many, that the presidential bell had to be used to restore order.

During a somewhat heated discussion over the position of the company at the date of the adjustment of the auditors' account: Mr. Maroni being hard pressed by Mre. Mercinier adroitly shielded himself behind the auditors certificate which drew from Mre. Mercinier a contemptuous shrug of the shoulders, the learned advocate having apparently as little respect for the obscurity of British book-keeping as the directors have shewn for English Company Law : he however, handsomely acknowledged that his remarks were in no way personal to the auditors of the company. The

Attention was drawn by a shareholder to the fact that creditors had entered actions against the company and that probably any decision for voluntary liquidation might be quashed by the decision of the court. It was therefore probably to avoid this contingency that Mre. Mercinier made provision for their representation on the committee inspection which he proposed.

His amendment to the motion of the directors was submitted and carried by a large majority, to the effect that a committee of inspection be appointed consisting of Messrs. Alfred Nahman, Pappa and J. Aghion with power to add two further members to be nominated by the creditors of the company and to lay their report before a meeting of shareholders to be convened for the 24th. inst.
Mr. Vattenbella withdrew his motion of a vote of censure on the Directors and proceedings terminated.
Over 100 members attended including 14 members of the bar: 47.000 shares were represented including 23.000 of Messrs. Arditti.
At the conclusion of the meeting all the directors present tendered their resignation.

div.head: BONAPARTE IN EGYPT.
div.p: LATE HAJI BROWNE'S BOOK.
(Continued)

On the subject of their oppression by the Mameluks and their history prior to the French invasion, Haji Browne is far more interesting than he is on their contact with Europeans, and we confess that we found this, which he meant presumably as an introduction the most attractive part of the book; for against these old invaders he seems to have no quarrel, but against France and England he seems to bear a grudge; 80 much so in fact that he almost confuses the two in his estimation of their faults, and seems to regard the English as in some measure inheriting and carrying on the injustices of the French. We cannot perhaps do better than quote the following extract from a chapter entitled “Victors, and Vanquished" wherein this confusion of attitude is illustrated ; indeed this chapter is practically the key to the whole book; the others are repetitions of the same attitude placed round different details :

"It will be seen, then, that the condition of the Egyptians at the time of the French invasion was, in a broad way, similar to that of the Saxons under the Normans, but we need not go back to the time when Garth bewailed the condition of his countrymen to find the masses of English people but little better off in this respect than were the Egyptians under the Mamaluks. When in 1795 Bishop Horsley, speaking in the House of Lords, said "he did not know what the mass of the people in any country had to to do with the laws but to obey them"; and the Chief Justice in sentencing Muir, cried, "As for the rabble, who have nothing but personal property, what hold has the nation on them ?" they might both have been speaking for the Mamaluk rulers of Egypt and yet they spoke nothing more than the sentiment of their class. In many other ways the condition of the English people at the close of the eighteenth century was not only not better than that of the Egyptians, but absolutely worse. In Egypt the people suffered from the Corvée—that is to say, their liability to force labour. In England the press-gangs dragged them from their homes for Foreign service. In Egypt the people were liable to be flogged or executed on the least pretext at the whim of their rulers ; in England they were subject to the same penalties by "just process of law,” interpreted by such humane and benevolent persons as the two men whom I have just quoted. Let anyone who will study the records of the time with regard to the condition of the people of England, those of France, and those of Egypt, and they cannot fail to see that the advantage lay with the Egyptians. I have elsewhere tried to show that the Egyptians looked upon the evils from which they suffered, and it must be obvious from what I have said that this people had but little inducement to revolt. Could they have risen and annihilated the Mamaluks the only result would have been the immediate invasion of the country by a Turkish army that they could not possibly withstand and which would not fail to exact a terrible penalty from them for their temporary success. In Egypt then the people had to endure much, but the ills that afflicted them were intermittent, coming upon them only now and then after longer or shorter intervals of at least comparative peace and comfort, reminding one indeed of the hurricanes that ravage the South Sea Islands with death and destruction, but, swiftly passing, leave the people once more to the enjoyment of the indolent, care-free life they ordinarily live. How different had it been in France just before the Revolution. In Egypt the people always had the Ulema to plead their cause, and if these commonly urged them to the exercise of patience and submission, they did so with a sympathy that was real. In France priest and politician alike were aloof from the people and the evils that were crushing these were growing steadily day by day with increasing force, with no intermission, and with no possibility but one that found its expression in the cry of "Down with the aristocrats." There was no such agony of want and misery for the people of Cairo as there was for the people of Paris in those bitter days when the Revolution, unseen but with many warning mutterings was gathering to itself hearts of men, that these might form its army of vengeance upon that "cream of civilisation" that had grown so exquisitely fine and sensitive that it had lost its natural sympathies and ceased to be conscious of its fellow-ship with any humanity not fitted to adorn its saloons. To the Egyptian theory of "Down with the Beys” would but have meant "Up with the Turks."

To the French the cry of "Down with the aristocrats” meant "Up with myself” and so justice in the crimson garb of vengeance, swept over the land and, like another Frankstein, aristocratic brutality fled from its own creation. In England, bad as was the condition of the people, the circumstances that determined their action were very different from those that controlled the French or the Egyptians. In Egypt everything tended to discourage the people from any attempt to permanently better their condition. In France everything drove them to desperate but victorious struggle. In England the people had every incentive to action of another type. There the principle of constitutional government was recognised, and if the laws were “the most savage that ever disgraced a statute book” it was within the bounds of possibility to hope for their inprovement. The right of the people to govern themselves was not yet admitted, but their right to be heard was only denied by a class which was not beyond attack or defeat by legal means, and in the last resort rebellion was possible and by no

means foredoomed to failure. The English were in the same position as the Egyptians in one respect, namely," that it was not a change in the form of government or the normal and proper condition of the people that they needed, but simply the abolition of evils that were accidental and not essential to that form or those conditions. To the French reform had become virtually impossible. No making or mending of laws or regulations will mend the hearts of men. The Beys of Egypt, the governing class in England, and the aristocrats in France were all heartlessly tyrannical, but the Beys were so through capricious selfishness, the English through distorted views of justice and right, and the French through callous, persistent inhumanity. The difference in character of the tyranny under which each of the three peoples were groaning was, therefore, not less than that of their hopes for its mitigation.
(To be continued.)

div.head: THE NILE FLOOD.
div.p: The following note on the Nile Flood has been submitted to the Minister of Public Works by the Acting Adviser to that Ministry under date of the 9th instant :

There has been little change in the condition of the Nile flood during the past week. "The level of the river has been steady throughout, and though it continues very low there is not as yet any sign of the beginning of the final fall.
The flood has so far been very similar to and slightly worse than that of 1899, but the levels in the far South are now being a little better maintained.
The rise due to the improvement noticed at Roseires about the 22nd August has just reached Cairo, and will probably prove to be the maximum for the year.
It is lower than that of any year of which we have record excepting only 1877.

The level of the river in Egypt will probably remain very nearly steady for another fortnight at least, during which time fair progress should be made with the filling of the backward basins, but many of the small canals are flowing very feebly.
The conditions North of Assiout except for a few comparatively small areas to the East of the river remain quite satisfactory.
Ghazi Ahmad Moukhtar Pasha will return from Austria, towards the end of this month.
Dr. Gumprecht, German Consul at Cairo left yesterday for Port Said, en route for Europe.
Commander Joseph Sakakini Bey is returning to Egypt on the 15th inst., from Brussels, where he has been attending the Masonic Congress, in the interests of the Scottish Rite.

Mr. F. Barker, sub-director of the accounts department of the Customs Administration, has received an autographed photograph from Emperor Francois Joseph of Austria. Many of our readers will remember that Mr. Barker was formerly reader and private secretary to the late Empress Elizabeth. We congratulate Mr. Barker upon the distinction which he has obtained from the Emperor of Austria.
The order placing Captain and Brevet Major M. Lowndes, Royal Dublin Fusilers, on duty with the draft for the 1st Battalion, Alexandria, has been cancelled.

On commissioning for duty with the Mediterranean Fleet, Captain Phipps Hornby will hoist his pennant on the battleship "Glory,” which, as already intimated. will replace the battleship "Venerable" as flagship of Prince Louis of Battenberg, second in command of the Fleet. Captain Phipps Hornby is well known on the station.
A. S. C.
The Course will be open for galloping horses on Monday next the 16th inst. from 6 to 9 a.m.

div.head: REFORMS IN MACEDONIA.
div.p: THE AUSTRO-RUSSIAN PROPOSALS.
The Vienna correspondent of the "Times" states that in well-informed circles in that city it is stated that Italy has accepted the Austro-Russian scheme of judicial reforms for Macedonia.

The “Neue Freie Press” publishes a despatch from Constantinople containing some account of the Austro-Russian scheme. Its objects, says the despatch, are first to guarantee that Christians and Musulmans shall meet with equal and impartial justice ; secondly, that the Judges be rendered as independentas possible by regular and certain payment of their salaries; thirdly, that Christian inspectors be appointed to see that justice be not administered by the Musulman Judges to the disadvantage of
Christians. According to the despatch, the || Austro-Russian scheme is rather an "acte de

contrôle et de régularisation" than an ambistions reform. It infringes in no way the Sultan's I prerogatives, and offers no valid pretext for opposition on the part of the Porte. The despatch concludes with the expression of a hope that the Powers will be firm and unanimous in insisting upon the prompt acceptance of the scheme by Turkey.

div.head: INVESTMENT. IN EGYPT.
div.p: SOURCE OF WEALTH.
(Continued.)

In ordinary times it might soffice in proof of the assertion that the economic condition of Egypt is absolutely sound to cite (a) from an article in the Economiste European (November, 1906) the opinion of a well-known French writer, an opinion given after independent examination of the facts, that “the actual prosperity of Egypt is founded on a very solid besis in that it is the ontcome of a plan off well conceived reforms, the methodical execution of which has at least doubled the value of native produce"; and (b) from the report of that able financier and administrator, Lord Cromer, who in 1905, and again in 1906, emphasized the pregnant sentence : «The material prosperity of Egypt rests on a basis of somewhat exceptional solidity.” But high sounding generalities, even when uttered by such eminent authorities do not always carry home to the carefal investor's mind the same sturdy convinction that is born of the study of a concise statement of facts. So, as confidence in Egyptian securities has lately been so very rudely shaken, it may be advisable, before proceeding further, to set forth briefly a few of the verities which justify his Lordship's, and the French economist's, sound contention.

England's task began by placing Egypt's finances on a firm basis; by adopting the wise policy of low taxation; by establishing evenhanded justice throughout the country; by substituting for the old (and sole) bond uniting rulers and ruled (viz., reliance on, and fear of, saperior, autocratic and overwhelming force) those kindlier bonds of sympathy and contentment which engender in the masses a growth of confidence in their new rolers' good intentions; and, finally, England made "steady progress” her watchword in the pursuance of a firm, strong, just and enlighteued programme.

The foundation of the wealth of Egypt is her agricultural land, fertilized yearly by the deposits brought down by the Nile flood from the distant inland seas (Nyanzas), and her prosperity does not depend on manufactures and indastries, which in one decade may flourish and in the next pale and wither under the sun of alien competition. And I would lay great stress on the fact that the price of Delta farm lands has not in any way been adversely effected by the recent Bourse troubles. On the contrary, a few farmers having lands quite close to the principal towns took advantage of the boom to sell small cultivable plots as building lots at ten times their agricultural value. Remembering that land remains stationary whilst industries often quit one centre or country for another, British administrators have from the outset directed their earnest efforts towards improving farm lands, to increasing the productivity of the soil, and to bringing under cultivation new areas, while endeavouring to supply more constantegater to the hold.

Irrigation was the first means employed to these ends. Not only has the enorinously increased supply of the fertilizing Nile water permitted and the bringing under cultivation of a superior acreage, but it has insured the cotton crop against failure from insufficient summer water. It is perhaps an open question (for over-cropping must ever be a very serious danger) whether farmers in Egypt are, or are not, justified in sowing with cotton more than one-third of their lands ; but, be this as it may, the Delta farmer of to-day does as a matter of fact put one-half (and sometimes even as much as 65%, thongh the actual tendency is rather to reduce it again) of his farm under cotton, for he has acquired absolute confidence in the impartial working of the “rotation" system, and he considers the supply of summer water as assured. The storage of water at Assouan has likewise benefited the farmers in Upper Egypt by enabling them to grow two crops annually-cotton in summer and sugar or cereals in winter in the place of their one winter crop as aforetime. As regards the cost of constructing the chief reservoir, it was comparatively so small that it has been estimated that each million gallons held up by the Assouan Dam only costs the Government £10, while it has even been alleged that the groat work yields, year by year, a return of the total capital outlay.
(To be continued.)

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
div.p: Le "Phare d'Alexandrie" trouve peu géné rense notre critique municipale de mardi, parce que la plupart des conseillers, étant absents, ne peuvent se défendre. Mais n'y a-t-il pas l'apologiste habituel de nos édiles, n'y a-t-il pas le “Phare", pour répondre ? Et le distingué viceprésident de la Municipalité, S.E. Schiess Pacha et plusieurs membres de la Commission ne sont-ils pas là ? On nous permettra d'ailleurs de
trouver extraordinaire qu'une institution charIgée de la direction des affaires publiques s'ab
sente pendant la moitié de l'année où nous (avrions le plus besoin de son concours. | Notre excellent confrère nous en veut sur

tout d'avoir affable, nos réflexions da titre d'opinion publique. Est-ce parce qu'il croit avoir le monopole de cette denrée ? Dans ce cas, il peut se détromper car une petite enquête faite I par lui-même loi aura vite démontré que l'en

semble de la population critique notre institution dirigeante plus vivement encore que nous ne l'avons fait. Dans les lieux de réunion, dans les cafés, les cercles, etc. on accuse ouvertement la presse de se taire à dessein sur les abus dont elle est témoin. C'est pour avoir été l'objet de semblables accusations que nous croyons devoir nous faire de temps à antre les interprètes du mécontentement général à l'égard de notre Municipalité.

Notre confrère, d'autre part, se montre peu confiant dans les résultats du suffrage universel. Aussi n'est-ce pas un tel mode d'élection que nous réclamons, mais une extension rationnelle du droit de vote à toute la partie instruite de la population qui paye l'impôt. C'est la d'ail. leurs une discussion de longue haleine qui ne peut trouver place ici ; ce que nons en ayong dit suffit pour l'instant

La franchise avec laquelle le "Phare d'Alex. andrie" reconnait le bien-fondé et l'exactitade des principaux griefs que nous avons formulés, l'incroyable brutalité des percepteurs municipaux, la canalisation déplorable, etc., n'est pas pour nous déplaire, et nous sommes prêts à constater avec lui que si notre édilité n'est pas un modèle da genre, elle n'est pas non plus l'épouvantail qu'il a eru voir dans notre article. Nous savons que des services, trop rares inalheureusement, fonctionnent bien, que évidemment des embellissements ont eu lieu depuis 20 ans, et lorsque nons avons énuméré les vices de l'institution, nous n'avons jamais eu la | pensée d'en méconnaître les bienfaits. Encore une fois il n'y a chez nous aucun parti-pris de dénigrement. Nous ne demandons pas mienx qoe d'avouer le bien, partout où il se trouve.

"La Réforme" qui nous a également gratifié d'une attaque, a, suivant son habitude, deplacé la question. Elle sonrit du carsctère utopique de la réforme de la loi électorale, que nous proposons. Et après, dit-elle, est-ce que ça marchera mieux ! Et toujours gouailleuse, elle nous réclame sur la loi electorale et nos divers griefs des explications, que nous avons déjà données dans l'article qn'elle incrimine.
Voici la conclusion de son article :

"La loi peut être défectuease, mais ce n'est pas à cause de ses défauts que les égouts répandent une odeur léthifère et que nous mangeons de la cuisse de chameau au lieu de la culasse de boeof.” Pourtant, la "Réforme" constatera avec nous que si nous mangeons du chameau au lieu de boeuf, si les égouts empestent, si nous vivons dans un nuage de poussière, si nous sommes brutalisés par les percepteurs municipaux, si nous sommes volés "et nargués par nos fournisseurs, si la crise des loyers est rendue plus aigüe, c'est parce que la Municipalité ne surveille pas les marchés, ne s'occupe pas de la canalisation, ne balaye ni n'arrose suffisamment, ne s'intéresse pas aux locataires. A qui donc la "Réforme” voudra-t-elle faire croire que si, au lieu de conseillers mandataires de quelqnes containes d'intéressés, la loi envoyait au palais municipal des élus du peuple, il n'y aurait rien de changé dans les préoccupations municipales ? Sans vouloir prétendre qu'il n'y aurait plus d'abus, ce qui est une naïveté que nous lui laissons pour compte, il est certain qu'avec une telle modification de la loi electorale, l'agsainissement de la ville, la canalisation des rues, l'aréation des quartiers, la protection des locataires, le contrôle des marchés passeraient au premier rang, et c'est ce qne nous voulons.

Mais ne confondons pas, comme le fait à juste titre remarquer notre confrère, la question pratique et la guestion de principe. Laissons celle-ci pour de plus longues polémiques et examinous la question de fait, celle du travail de nos conseillers. C'est cette confusion qui a permis à la "Réforme" de tourner autour de la question sans l'aborder. Il s'agit en effet, de savoir si l'expérience de la Municipalité actuelle a été satisfaisante. Nous avons exposé les griefs de la population : nos conseillers n'ont encore rien fait pour l'hygiène proprement dite, c'est-à-dire pour la canalisation des rues et l'aération des quartiers, les égouts répandent partout une odeur nauséabonde, les rues à de rares exceptions près sont mal entretenues, il y a des vidanges qni coulent à ciel ouvert dans certains endroits, les marchés ne sont pas surveillés, les poids et mesures ne sont pas contrôlés, les locataires sont tournés en dérision, les taxes sont brutalement perçues ; et en face de cette inertie, de cette incapacité, et de cette hostilité à peine déguisée à l'égard de la classe laborieuse, nous voyons le budget croitre dans d'énormes I proportions mais le gaspillage administratif augmentant encore plus rapidement, on songe parait-il à créer de nouveaux impôts ! On nous répond : mais voyez Alexandrie d'aujourd'hni et comparez-là avec ce qu'elle était autrefois. Est-ce par hazard la Municipalité qui a construit les nonveaux quartiers ? Où passe tout l'argent des contribuables? Comparez, par exemple, les dépenses de 1897 avec celles de 1907 et dites-nous dans quel gonftre les recettes qui ont quadruplé sont englouties? Voilà la question. C'est à quoi il faut répondre.
Nous espérons que cette fois l'apologiste municipal n'aura plusaucun prétexte pour éviter la discussion. Il s'agit de faits matériels que chacun pent contrôler. S'ils sont faux, rien
n'est plus facile pour lui qne d'en démontrer | l’inanité. Cela fait, il n'y aura plus lieu d'examiner la question de principe, puisque, l'insti
tution actuelle donnant toute satisfaction, il | serait oisenx de procéder à une réforme inutile.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à 11h. 1/2 a.m.) Sans pouvoir dire que la séance d'aujourd'hui a été brillante, nous sommes pourtant heureux de constater qu'il y a une certaine amélioration, sinon dans la cote dont les fluctuations sont assez inégales, au moins dans le mouvement des transactions qui ont été tant soit peu plus actives. On en augure bien pour la tenue de la semaine prochaine. C'est ce que l'avenir de cidera.

A signaler en particulier la Delta Light qui, après avoir débuté à 9 13/16, cours d'hier, est revenue en cloture à 9 3/4 acheteurs, avec affaires. La Deferred Delta, plus éprouvée, a perdu 1/2 livre à 8. Il a été fait au début 300 Cassa di Sconto à 36 1/2; plus tard le cours s'est relevé à 38 1/2, pour finir à 38 acheteurs, soit 1 fr. de hausse. Les 75 actions Cassa, anciernes, et non nouvelles comme nous l'avions dit par erreur, qni n'avaient pu trouver d'acquéreurs à l'enchère d'hier, ont été prises aujourd'hui au prix de 38 1/4. A noter encore une demande en Ritz qui se consolide à 1/2 et en Privilégiées Béhéra qui sont demandées à 4 livres.

L'Agricole se consolide à 8 1/16 acheteurs et la National Bank s'avance de 20 1/16 à 20 3/16, les Tramways d'Alexandrie de 143 à 143 1/2 acheteurs les Priviligiées et de 300 à 301 les Dividendes, et les Nungovich Hotels de 13 5/8 à 13 3/4.

D'autre part, l’Alexandria Water fléchit de 11 3/8 à 11 1/4, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire de 202 à 200, la Land Bank de 7 3/16 à 7 1/8, l'Union Foncière de 4 7/16 à 4 5/16 et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/16 à 4.
Parmi les valeurs d'ordre secondaire, les Markets baissent de 28 à 27/9, tandis que le Comptoir progresse de 2 9/32 à 2 3/8 ven. deurs l'ancienne et de 2 11/32 à 2 7/16 la nouvelle
Et c'est tout.

La Sidi Salem Estates Co., après les diverses ventes dont nous avons eu l'occasion de parler ces derniers temps, vient encore d'en conclure une nouvelle : il s'agit de 64 feddans cédés à raison de £100 le feddan. Ces nombreuses transactions de sociétés agricoles montrent que les terrains de culture n'ont pas été atteints par la crise.

A la troisième assemblée d'hier de la Bourse and Banking les actionnaires ont vivement protesté contre la proposition présidentielle de prononcer la liquidation amiable de la société. On a nommé une commission, composée de MM. S. Pappo, J. Aghion et A. Nahman, pour vérifier les comptes et le bilan. Une 4me assemblée se réunira le 24 courant pour délibérer sur le résultat de l'enquête et se prononcer sur la ligne de conduite à suivre. M. Arditi, froissé de ce qu'on ne lui avait pas réservé le fauteuil présidentiel, n'a pas comparu, En fin de séance les administrateurs ont démissionné. Reste à savoir ce que les créanciers feront d'ici au 24 conrant. Ainsi la Banquede Salonique a actionné la société en état de faillite pour le non paiement d'un effet d'environ 6,000 livres et l'as. signation est précisément pour cette date. Nous avions raison de dire que les actionnaires n'étaient pas au bout de leurs pèlerinages ni de leurs surprises. Ce qui se passe pour cette société est vraiment prodigieux.

div.head: Circulaire A. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Jeudi 12 Septembre.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 4 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé hier de 1/4 à 82 3/8. L'Unifiée est restée à 101 3/4. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 à 20 3/8 et la Daïra également 1/8 à 12 7/8. L'Agricole a été soutenue à 8 1/4 de même qne la Delta Light à 9 3/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est resté invarié à 687. La Banque d'Athènes a perdu 1 franc à 112 et les Lots Turcs 1 franc à 165.
Ici, la séance a été à beaucoup d'égards meildeure qu'hier. Les transactions ont été plus nombreuses et l'activité générale dans tous les compartiments.

On se rend compte, à l'évidence, que les cours offrent à nouveau des possibilités très grandes de plus-values et l'on achète avec la conviction que les risques sont à peu près nuls. Aussi les cours n'ont-ils pas en beancoop de peine à se relever de leur légère défaillance d'hier, et, si quelques valeurs clôturent en nonvelle rétrogradation, il n'y a là qu’un effet des liquidations furcles qui se poursuivent tant au Caire qu's Alexandrie.

La tendance nous semble meillenre, et l'on pense généralement que nous entrons dans une période de fermeté sinon de hausse ; on se base sur la tenue de nos valeurs à Londres et sur l'amélioration survenue sur le marché monétaire international.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank est en progrès à 20 1/16-1/8. L'Agricole reste à 8 1/16. La Cassa di Sconto continue à setasser à 35-36. La Banque d'Athènes retombe à 109 et le Comptoir Financier à 2 5/16.

La Delta Light est en bonne demande à 9 5/8. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire fléchissent à 198. La Daïra Sanieh rétrograde à 12 k-11/16. Le Crédit Foncier n'est pas plus soutenu à 683 et les obligations anciennes sont faibles à 301-302, La Béhéra se relève à 20 1/4. L'Allotmentaccentue son tassement à 2 3/16-1/4, tandis que sa part remonte à P.T. 61. La fondateur Enterprise and Development hausse encore à 10 11/16. La Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux est parmi les plus fermes à 2 1/4, alors que sa part progresse à P.T. 44.
L'Anglo-American Nile baisse à 2 3/8-7/16 et les Omnibus Automobiles à 1/8.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Egyptian Hotels (Baehler) remontent à 6 1/16-1/8 et les Nungovich de même à 13 5/8-11/16. Les National Hotels suivent la tendance à 2 1/2-9/16. Les Ritz, quoique passablement demandés, s'en tiennent à 0 1 2-9/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Markets se ressaisissent à 27/9 et les Aboukir à 27/6, tandis que les Hooker reculent à 0 3/8.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres en date du 7 courant, les passages suivants :
"Nos fords d'Etats aussi bien que les étrangers ont conservé beaucoup de fermeté pendant toute la semaine en revue, avec des alternatives insignifiantes de hausse et de baisse.

Malgré cette bonne tenue de nos Consolidés et particulièrement des chemins de fer améri. cains, le marché est plutôt calme. On ne croit pas à une grande activité pendant le mois de Septembre mais on a, par contre, bon espoir qu'Octobre ramènera, des transactions plus saivies.
En somme, les milieux financiers sont légè. rement indécis et l'on attend de tous côtés la fin de la période de transition qu'est le mois de Septembre.
Les valeurs égyptiennes ont été en général très peu mouvementées la semaine durant, mais leur tendance reste néanmoins bonne.

La National Bank et l'Agricultural se sont maintenues calmes aux environs de 20 1/4 et 8 1/4. La Daïra de 12 1/2 a avancé à 13 sur les rumeurs d'une répartition de 16/- par action en Octobre accompagné de la distribution des actions du Crédit Foncier. La Sidi Salem dont on n'avait pas entendu parler depuis des mois a été demandée à 2 sans trouver vendears.

La situation du marché monétaire est favorable et par suite de l'abondance de l'argent les taux d'escompte ont de nouveau été faibles. On a pu emprunter à vue à 2 1/2 puis 1 1/2 % et 2 1/2-2 3/4 % à 8 jours.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

- MM. les actionnaires de The Associated Cotton Ginners of Egypt Ltd. sont convoqués en assemblée générale extraordinaire, au siège de la compagnie à Alexandrie, pour le 25 Septembre courant à 5 heures p.m.
A l'ordre du jour : Confirmer les résolutions votées provisoirement à l'assemblée du 10 courant, concernant les modifications apportées à l'art. 87 des Statuts.
-- Le même jour dans les mêmes locaux à 5 h. 1/2 p.m. aura lieu une seconde assemblée générale extraordinaire de cette Société, à l'effet de nommer de nouveanx administrateurs.

div.head: THE UNITED EGYPTIAN LANDS. LTD.

I. DES CLAYES.
Secretary in Egypt.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L’Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance dà Public qu'il sera procérlé, le Lundi trente Septembre courant, à neuf heures du matin, aux Magasins Généraux de Boulac, Caire, à la vente aux enchères publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, de cinq vieilles machines pour imprimerie avec leurs accessoires qui se trouvent à l'atelier de l'Imprimerie de l'Administration en face de la gare du Caire où on peut les examiner chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à midi, le Vendredi et jours fériés exceptés.

Les conditions de vente relatives à ces machines peuvent être consultées au Bureau de Mr. le Chef da Service des Magasins Généraux à Boulac, Caire, et à celui de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary, Alexandrie, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m., le Dimanche et jours fériés exceptés.

Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire devra, au préalable, verser à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration une somme de L.E. 5 (cinq Livres Egyptiennes) à titre de dépôt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jus. qu'à concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montant de l'offre agréée et enlever à ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés dans un délai de sept jours à compter de la date de l'avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront être faites sur papier timbré de trente millèmes, si l'intéressé ne peut pas assister aux enchères publiques et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le reçu du versement du dépôt provisoire, seront adressés par la poste sous pli recommandé à :- .

Monsieur le Chef du Service des Magasins des Chemins de fer de l'Etat à Boulac (Caire). et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure por tant la suscription suivante : "Offre pour achat de vieilles machines pour imprimerie."
Toute offre faite ou déposée ultérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L''Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.

div.head: THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
div.p: FIGHTING AT TADDERT.
DISPERSAL OF TRIBES.
GERMANY'S ATTITUDE.
CASABLANCA, September 12.

General Drude began his advance to Taddert at six o'clock in the morning. Two squares composed of six companies each, with field batteries and four mountain guns, and all the cavalry were engaged. Several bodies of Arabs who offered resistance were swept away at the point of the bayonet, till Taddert was sighted, After a preparatory bombardment the infantry charged, routing the Moors. The camp was burnt. The French then returned to camp: their loss was small.

(Later). The French had i killed and 6 wounded. There was nothing of real value in the camp, the loot having been removed to the interior. The effect of the move is doubtful : the enemy is too raw to regard defeat seriously. The tribes, recently concentrated, have apparently dispersed owing to scarcity of food, leaving a small force to hold the camp till fresh supplies have been collected. (Reuter)
CASABLANCA, September 12.

General Drude yesterday directed a reconnoitre during the afternoon. Profiting by the mist be surprised the camp at Taddert The Moorish encampment was burnt down and the - Mehalla dispersed. Cannon fire was used in the pursuit of the enemy. The cruiser "Gloire" participated efficiently in the fight. The Moorish losses were considerable ; the French lost i killed and 6 wonnded. The Spanish troops had a slight engagement. (Havas)
PARIS, September 12.

The German reply to France regarding Morocco is the object of much criticism. In France the general impression in political circles seems to be, that whatever ulterior motives are involved they can have nothing in common with the desire to facilitate the onerous task of France. What Germany concedes with one hand seems to be withdrawn with the other. One thing is clear, that Germany entirely reserves the future without frankly approving the present. (Reuter)

div.head: THE "STANDART” WRECK.
div.p: ROYAL FAMILY LEAVE VESSEL.
ST. PETERSBURG, September 12.
The Royal family have been safely transferred to the cruiser “Asia”. The public here are in ignorance of the accident. There was no mention of it in the morning papers. (Reuter)
HELSINGFORS, September 12.
The “Standart” has a rent 42 feet long amidships and another forward. The rocks were not marked on the chart. (Reuter)

div.head: SIR H. MACLEAN.
div.p: NEGOTIATIONS WITH LONDON,
LONDON, September 12.

El Raisuli's terms have reached the Foreign Office. Informal negotiations are now proceeding between Mr. Lowther and a representative of El Raisuli. These are hoped shortly to result in Sir H. Maclean's release. (Reuter)

div.head: MONTE CARLO MURDER.
div.p: PARIS, September 12.
The Monte Carlo Murder was reconstituted yesterday. Mistress Goold's repudiation of actual participation in the crime was inshaken.
(Reuter)

div.head: MOTOR CAR FATALITY.
div.p: FLORENCE, September 12.
Prince Wiviejschi, a Viennese nobleman residing here, has been killed in a motor car accident.
(Reuter)

SUNK GREEK FLEET.
CONCESSION FOR SALVAGE.
LONDON, September, 12.
A syndicate bere has obtained a concession from the Greek Government to raise the fleet sunk at Navarino, the value of which, with the treasure, is estimated at £1,500,000. (Reuter)
AN ARBITRATION TREATY.
The Hague, September 12.
Italy and the Argentine Republic are concluding a general arbitration treaty through their delegates here. It has been drafted to serve as a model for others. (Reuter)
THE PERSIAN PARLIAMENT.
TEHERAN, September 12.
After an animated discussion Parliament agreed to obey the Shah's command to give the new Cabinet a fortnight's trial, when the ministers found wanting would be replaced.
(Reuter)
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
The Hague, September 12.
MM. Bourgeois and Marshall, the first French and German delegates at the Conference, have left, needing rest. They will return in a few days. (Reuter)

div.head: THE UNREST IN TURKEY.
div.p: The recent incidents at Bitlis and Beirut, to which we referred in our leading article of yesterday although reported in the “Times” and most other English newspapers, do not seem to have attracted the attention they deserve. Coming as they do after a whole series of similar manifestations, they throw a vivid light on the present state of feeling both of the army and of the civil population of Turkey.

At Bitlis the Musulman citizens expelled their Vali by main force, and, indeed, as he was not willing to go quietly, subjected him to somewhat rough treatment in the process. In telegrams to the Palace they assured the Sultan of their loyalty, but at the same time said quite plainly that they could not tolerate the reinstatement of the obnoxious Ferid ; sooner than live under his rule they would abandon all that they had and leave the country. Last year risings of the same kind took place at Erzerum and Kastamuni, and in those places the population demanded not only the removal of their Valis but the abolition of certain oppressive taxes.

At Beirut a body of some 2,000 soldiers, who after serving eight or nine years in Yemen, were being sent home without their pay, forced the captain of the transport to take them into the port, in defiance of express orders to the contrary. They landed in detachments and, seizing the Vali, the treasurer, and the military commandant, held them as hostages until their pay, amounting to nearly £40,000 sterling, had been handed over to them. They then returned to their ship, and, on being landed at another port, quietly dispersed and made their way home. This is only one case out of dozens where the Turkish soldier, probably the most patient and obedient as well as among the most courageous of all soldiers, has resorted to open mutiny, after finding that less drastic methods were of no avail for obtaining the redress of his grievances. . . .

A striking feature of nearly all these mani. festations, says a correspondent to the “Times," bas been the self-control and discipline shown by those taking part in them. European witnesses dilate on the orderly way in which the expulsion of the Anatolian Valis was conducted. . . .

It is evident that the frequent occurrence of such incidents is a very important sign of the times in Turkey. Of course the immediate causes of the mutinies in the army have been specific military grievances. These grievances are neither few nor light; the soldier is neglected to an extent that is almost incredible in an army which was at one time the best organized in the world. . . .

Of the existing discontent the incidents in three of the Anatolian vilayets are not the only evidence. Europeans whose occupation brings them into touch with Turks, especially those who speak the language well enough to get on confidential terms with them, and who are in the habit of making business trips into the interior, testify to the existence throughout the country of a rapidly growing feeling of exasperation. One exceptionally coolheaded business man, who recently revisited places and friends in Asia Minor after an interval of three or four years, was so impressed by what he saw and heard that he regards a violent explosion of discontent as certain to occur in the near future, if a serious attempt is not made to remedy the most crying abuse of the administration. . . . The other day a foreign diplomatist who has been many years here expressed in conversation with an English friend his regret that the British Admiralty had withdrawn the small cruiser which used to be kept in the Bosporus, and the reason he gave for his regret was that, in a place where every section of the population is so discontented, and has such good reason to be discontented, anything might happen at any moment, and it might some day be of supreme importance to have help at hand, instead of having to wait a day, or even a couple of days, before it could arrive.

There is probably a certain amount of exaggeration in all the opinions which have just been quoted. Well-informed Turks do not regard a serious outbreak as at all likely to occur, at any rate for some years to come ; and certainly the order and self restraint which have been such remarkable features of the incidents already mentioned give us some ground for thinking that neither European nor native Christians will run much danger, even if there should be a general rising against the Government. . . .

It might be thought that, if the Turks are so discontented as they are here represented as being, they would welcome the interventions of the Powers in favour of reforms. This is far from being the case, and indeed it would be extraordinary if Farks differed so entirely from other nations as to relish the interference in their internal affairs of people who are not only foreigners, but aliens in race and creed. Moreover, there are few Turks, if any, who believe that the action of the Powers is dictated by any disinterested concern for the good of Turkey. . . .

But it is time to consider the causes which have created this discontent among people who demand so little from their Government. . . . Perhaps the most potent cause is to be found in the character of the men who are now sent to the provinces as governors and governors-general. The old type of Vali &c., was frequently brutal and corrupt, but he had generally served a long apprenticeship in smaller posts, knew his business, and understood the people and their wants. Since the appointments to these posts have passed from the hands of the Porte, which, with all its shortcomings, had some sense of responsibility, into the hands of Palace favourites,

they have been used to reward their friends, and have been given to men who possess the vices of their predecessors and none of their virtues. . . .

The elique at the Palace is apt to take credit to itself for the great extension of the railway system which has taken place under its auspices. No one would deny that railways are a good thing for the country, or that the districts through which they pass have been made more prosperous by them. But the corrupt way in which the concessions have been given has brought it about that in almost every case the price paid has been out of all proportion to the usefulness of the line, and, moreover, this price is paid in the shape of kilometric guarantees so arranged that, the less work the railways do, the greater is the profit which they make.

div.head: INDIAN LOYALTY.
div.p: TRIBUTE TO BRITISH RULE.

An appeal has been issued in India, signed by a number of the most influential noblemen and gentlemen of Bengal, to their fellow-countrymen, in reference to the unrest prevailing there. They especially desire its publication in this country, in-order to show that their feelings are not in sympathy with the present movement among some of their countrymen, and that they are, in fact, opposed to the agitation. The title "zeminder" after some of the names means "landholder.” The appeal is as follows :
AN APPEAL.

It has been a matter of deep concern to us to observe the growing discontent of the people of this country, which has lately manifested itself in certain quarters in violent speeches and newspaper articles. We desire at once to dissociate ourselves from these demonstrations, which only tend to alienate the Government and the people from each other. It would, of course, be futile to pretend that the horizon of politics is cloudless. We have arrived at one of those periodical crises which arise in every country and which are beneficial to it or the reverse, according to the manner in which they are met. It is a crisis which calls for deep and earnest reflection on both sides, and not for noisy or violent declamation,

The crying need of the moment is amity and good feeling between the various communities, wholehearted sympathy on the part of the rulers for the people under their charge, and co-operation on the part of all who have the real interest of the country at heart, It has been grievous to us to find so much energy and patriotism diverted into wrong channels, and we cannot too strongly condemn the tone and temper displayed by certain journals, both English and Indian, which have exercised an influence hostile in the last degree to the promotion of friendly feelings among different sections of the community,

There has been more than one disagreement in the past between popular sentiment in India and the policy which the Government has seen fit to pursue, but those disagreements have never led to any serious estrangement, or proved otherwise thar. helpful, by throwing light upon administrative problems, and eventually bringing the two parties to a better mutual understanding. We firmly believe that such will be the outcome of the present situation, if the same qualities of restraint and moderation on one side and consideration for public opinion on the other are brought to boar upon it, which has saved it more than once in days gone by.

We venture to assert that the bulk of the people of the country are loyal and law-abiding. We now appeal to our countrymen, Hindus and Mohammedans, for a display of the practical good sense which some of our critics deny to us. We appeal to them to disconntenance any wild and mischievous propaganda which tends to encourage disaffection to Btitish rule, or to create feelings of animosity between different classes and communities in India ; for it is this tendency which furnishes the occasion and the excuse for the repressive measures which have recently been resorted to. Nor must we forget that, whatever may be its shortcomings, it is to British rule that we owo our present security of life and property, the spread of education, and the progress which India is now making according to modern civilised ideals.

This is emphatically the worst possible time to encourage unworthy sentiments of rancour and illfeeling. No true patriot will hesitate to range himself, with us, on the side of law and order at the present juncture, so as, on the one hand to restore the goodwill and harmony which, formerly prevailed among all classes and communities in India, and on the other hand, to leave the authorities no ground for bringing coercion to bear upon any group of British subjects.

div.head: ENGINEERING IN EGYPT
div.p: Turning from South Africa, where trade is bad, says “African Engineering," and yet Great Britain's share in it marvellously good, we find a double contrast in Egypt, where trade is extremely good but the British percentage much too low. Roughly speaking, Great Britain accounts for one-third of the total imports Pot Egypt, while other countries do the remaining two-thirds between them. It is true that in the returns of the Chamber of Commerce the goods supplied by India and all our other possessions are entered on the wrong side of the ledger-i e., are credited to "other countries” instead of Britain, but even if this were readjusted it is doubtful it the British share would represent more than a very small half of the total imports. Our general trade may, therefore, be classed as far below its proper proportion, and when we turn to the engineering imports, things are no better.
The following table shows the returns for the first five months of 1907. The figures are in L E. which equals about £1 0s. 6d. :—

table.head: EGYPT'S ENGINEERING IMPORTS FOR THE FIRST FIVE MONTHS OF 1907.

div.p: From the above it will be seen that Britain's share in engineering imports is less than half in a country where, if proper measures were taken, we ought to have at least four-fifths of the whole. And one of the many facts that go to prove this contention is that we habitually sell to Egypt at least three times as much agricultural plant as is furnished by all other countries together, and the actual returns for the latest month (May) show our share to have been nearly five times that of the rest of the world. Now, if we can do this in agricultural machinery, a line in which the temptation to deal in cheap American staff is greater, perhaps, than is the case with any other class of machinery, we ought to be able to do equally well with other goods. Yet the above table shows that we are not doing so, and it is this that we must set ourselves to overcome.

It will be seen that our share in cement imports was only two-fifths of the whole. This fact is largely due to the habitual practice of Continental firms in placing English labels on their own inferior stuff, and a further blow has been struck at our trade by the official acceptance by the Egyptian authorities of Belgian natural cement as being on an equality with real Portland cement-an absolutely unfair and pernicious measure. The introduction of cheap basio rails from Germany and elsewhere has had a bad effect on our metal imports, and kindred causes have told Against other products in which our share is lower than it should be.

Of course, the great drag on our machinery business in Egypt is the absolute disregard of British trade interests by British officials. The pandering to foreign susceptibilities, the consulting of foreign rather than British engineers on various subjects, and the apathy with regard to foreign financial intrigues, all tell heavily against us, and until this is removed or counteracted we shall never have anything in the semblance of fair play in dealing with that country, In spite of all these handicapping conditions, however, and although our share of the imports is too low, it is satisfactory to note that it is considerably more than double that of any other individual country. Still, it ought to be immensely more than that, especially in the engineering trade. We must hear in mind that the engineering imports from Great Britain are nearly all spread over a comparatively small pumber of our firms, who have made superhuman efforts to secure the business. We should like to see a great many more of our engineering firms enter the lists seriously, for the trade of Egypt is worth the getting.

div.head: MAKE YOUR OWN BRICKS AND SAVE TRANSPORT COSTS.
div.p: The "PROGRESS" Hand-power Brick Press.
Two men and a boy can make and stack from 5,000 to 7,000 bricks a day, after a little practice.
Pressure 12 to 15 tons per brick. Two bricks made by each stroke of the lever.
Especially suitable for making green bricks from semi-dry clay or other soil. We will report on suitability of soil if samples are submitted to us.
The press is packed for shipment fitted together.
It can be used immediately you get it. No expert fitting required. Very strongly built. Cannot get out of order. Most of the wearing parts reversible. Gross weight—packed in one case—9 cwt.
RUDHALL & CO., 16, Mark Lane, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the lates statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
